This worker type is available only for Glue version 3.0 or later Spark ETL jobs in the following Amazon Web Services Regions: US East (Ohio), US East (N. Virginia), US West (N. California), US West (Oregon), Asia Pacific (Mumbai), Asia Pacific (Seoul), Asia Pacific (Singapore), Asia Pacific (Sydney), Asia Pacific (Tokyo), Canada (Central), Europe (Frankfurt), Europe (Ireland), Europe (London), Europe (Spain), Europe (Stockholm), and South America (So Paulo).

  • For the G.8X worker type, each worker maps to 8 DPU (32 vCPUs, 128 GB of memory) with 512GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for jobs whose workloads contain your most demanding transforms, aggregations, joins, and queries. This worker type is available only for Glue version 3.0 or later Spark ETL jobs, in the same Amazon Web Services Regions as supported for the G.4X worker type.

  • For the G.025X worker type, each worker maps to 0.25 DPU (2 vCPUs, 4 GB of memory) with 84GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for low volume streaming jobs. This worker type is only available for Glue version 3.0 or later streaming jobs.

  • For the Z.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 M-DPU (8vCPUs, 64 GB of memory) with 128 GB disk, and provides up to 8 Ray workers based on the autoscaler.

CodeGenConfigurationNodes.documentation: The representation of a directed acyclic graph on which both the Glue Studio visual component and Glue Studio code generation is based.

ExecutionClass.documentation:
Indicates whether the job is run with a standard or flexible execution class. The standard execution-class is ideal for time-sensitive workloads that require fast job startup and dedicated resources.

The flexible execution class is appropriate for time-insensitive jobs whose start and completion times may vary.

Only jobs with Glue version 3.0 and above and command type glueetl will be allowed to set ExecutionClass to FLEX. The flexible execution class is available for Spark jobs.

SourceControlDetails.documentation: The details for a source control configuration for a job, allowing synchronization of job artifacts to or from a remote repository.

MaintenanceWindow.documentation:
This field specifies a day of the week and hour for a maintenance window for streaming jobs. Glue periodically performs maintenance activities. During these maintenance windows, Glue will need to restart your streaming jobs.

Glue will restart the job within 3 hours of the specified maintenance window. For instance, if you set up the maintenance window for Monday at 10:00AM GMT, your jobs will be restarted between 10:00AM GMT to 1:00PM GMT.

Name.documentation: The unique name that was provided for this job definition.
The name of the classifier.

JsonPath.documentation: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

CreateJsonClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a JSON classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

Name.documentation: The unique name that you give the transform when you create it.

Description.documentation: A description of the machine learning transform that is being defined. The default is an empty string.

InputRecordTables.documentation: A list of Glue table definitions used by the transform.

Parameters.documentation: The algorithmic parameters that are specific to the transform type used. Conditionally dependent on the transform type.

Role.documentation:
The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions. The required permissions include both Glue service role permissions to Glue resources, and Amazon S3 permissions required by the transform.

  • This role needs Glue service role permissions to allow access to resources in Glue. See Attach a Policy to IAM Users That Access Glue.

  • This role needs permission to your Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) sources, targets, temporary directory, scripts, and any libraries used by the task run for this transform.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

MaxCapacity is a mutually exclusive option with NumberOfWorkers and WorkerType.

  • If either NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType is set, then MaxCapacity cannot be set.

  • If MaxCapacity is set then neither NumberOfWorkers or WorkerType can be set.

  • If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

  • MaxCapacity and NumberOfWorkers must both be at least 1.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation:
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

If WorkerType is set, then NumberOfWorkers is required (and vice versa).

Timeout.documentation: The timeout of the task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this machine learning transform. You may use tags to limit access to the machine learning transform. For more information about tags in Glue, see Amazon Web Services Tags in Glue in the developer guide.

TransformEncryption.documentation: The encryption-at-rest settings of the transform that apply to accessing user data. Machine learning transforms can access user data encrypted in Amazon S3 using KMS.

TransformId.documentation: A unique identifier that is generated for the transform.

CatalogId.documentation: The catalog ID where the table resides.

DatabaseName.documentation: Specifies the name of a database in which you want to create a partition index.

TableName.documentation: Specifies the name of a table in which you want to create a partition index.

PartitionIndex.documentation: Specifies a PartitionIndex structure to create a partition index in an existing table.

CatalogId.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the catalog in which the partition is to be created.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the metadata database in which the partition is to be created.

TableName.documentation: The name of the metadata table in which the partition is to be created.

PartitionInput.documentation: A PartitionInput structure defining the partition to be created.

RegistryName.documentation: Name of the registry to be created of max length of 255, and may only contain letters, numbers, hyphen, underscore, dollar sign, or hash mark. No whitespace.

Description.documentation: A description of the registry. If description is not provided, there will not be any default value for this.

Tags.documentation: Amazon Web Services tags that contain a key value pair and may be searched by console, command line, or API.

RegistryArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the newly created registry.

Tags.documentation: The tags for the registry.

RegistryId.documentation: This is a wrapper shape to contain the registry identity fields. If this is not provided, the default registry will be used. The ARN format for the same will be: arn:aws:glue:us-east-2:<customer id>:registry/default-registry:random-5-letter-id.

SchemaName.documentation: Name of the schema to be created of max length of 255, and may only contain letters, numbers, hyphen, underscore, dollar sign, or hash mark. No whitespace.

DataFormat.documentation: The data format of the schema definition. Currently AVRO, JSON and PROTOBUF are supported.

Compatibility.documentation:
The compatibility mode of the schema. The possible values are:

  • NONE: No compatibility mode applies. You can use this choice in development scenarios or if you do not know the compatibility mode that you want to apply to schemas. Any new version added will be accepted without undergoing a compatibility check.

  • DISABLED: This compatibility choice prevents versioning for a particular schema. You can use this choice to prevent future versioning of a schema.

  • BACKWARD: This compatibility choice is recommended as it allows data receivers to read both the current and one previous schema version. This means that for instance, a new schema version cannot drop data fields or change the type of these fields, so they can't be read by readers using the previous version.

  • BACKWARD_ALL: This compatibility choice allows data receivers to read both the current and all previous schema versions. You can use this choice when you need to delete fields or add optional fields, and check compatibility against all previous schema versions.

  • FORWARD: This compatibility choice allows data receivers to read both the current and one next schema version, but not necessarily later versions. You can use this choice when you need to add fields or delete optional fields, but only check compatibility against the last schema version.

  • FORWARD_ALL: This compatibility choice allows data receivers to read written by producers of any new registered schema. You can use this choice when you need to add fields or delete optional fields, and check compatibility against all previous schema versions.

  • FULL: This compatibility choice allows data receivers to read data written by producers using the previous or next version of the schema, but not necessarily earlier or later versions. You can use this choice when you need to add or remove optional fields, but only check compatibility against the last schema version.

  • FULL_ALL: This compatibility choice allows data receivers to read data written by producers using all previous schema versions. You can use this choice when you need to add or remove optional fields, and check compatibility against all previous schema versions.

Description.documentation: An optional description of the schema. If description is not provided, there will not be any automatic default value for this.

Tags.documentation: Amazon Web Services tags that contain a key value pair and may be searched by console, command line, or API. If specified, follows the Amazon Web Services tags-on-create pattern.

SchemaDefinition.documentation: The schema definition using the DataFormat setting for SchemaName.

RegistryArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the registry.

SchemaArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema.

Description.documentation: A description of the schema if specified when created.

DataFormat.documentation: The data format of the schema definition. Currently AVRO, JSON and PROTOBUF are supported.

SchemaCheckpoint.documentation: The version number of the checkpoint (the last time the compatibility mode was changed).

LatestSchemaVersion.documentation: The latest version of the schema associated with the returned schema definition.

NextSchemaVersion.documentation: The next version of the schema associated with the returned schema definition.

Tags.documentation: The tags for the schema.

SchemaVersionId.documentation: The unique identifier of the first schema version.

SchemaVersionStatus.documentation: The status of the first schema version created.

DagNodes.documentation: A list of the nodes in the DAG.

DagEdges.documentation: A list of the edges in the DAG.

Language.documentation: The programming language of the resulting code from the DAG.

PythonScript.documentation: The Python script generated from the DAG.

ScalaCode.documentation: The Scala code generated from the DAG.

Name.documentation: The name for the new security configuration.

EncryptionConfiguration.documentation: The encryption configuration for the new security configuration.

Name.documentation: The name assigned to the new security configuration.

CreatedTimestamp.documentation: The time at which the new security configuration was created.

Role.documentation: The IAM Role ARN

Timeout.documentation: The number of minutes before session times out. Default for Spark ETL jobs is 48 hours (2880 minutes). Consult the documentation for other job types.

IdleTimeout.documentation: The number of minutes when idle before session times out. Default for Spark ETL jobs is value of Timeout. Consult the documentation for other job types.

DefaultArguments.documentation: A map array of key-value pairs. Max is 75 pairs.

Connections.documentation: The number of connections to use for the session.

MaxCapacity.documentation: The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when the job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB memory.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation: The number of workers of a defined WorkerType to use for the session.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when a job runs. Accepts a value of G.1X, G.2X, G.4X, or G.8X for Spark jobs. Accepts the value Z.2X for Ray notebooks.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker maps to 1 DPU (4 vCPUs, 16 GB of memory) with 94GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for workloads such as data transforms, joins, and queries, to offers a scalable and cost effective way to run most jobs.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 DPU (8 vCPUs, 32 GB of memory) with 138GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for workloads such as data transforms, joins, and queries, to offers a scalable and cost effective way to run most jobs.

  • For the G.4X worker type, each worker maps to 4 DPU (16 vCPUs, 64 GB of memory) with 256GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for jobs whose workloads contain your most demanding transforms, aggregations, joins, and queries. This worker type is available only for Glue version 3.0 or later Spark ETL jobs in the following Amazon Web Services Regions: US East (Ohio), US East (N. Virginia), US West (Oregon), Asia Pacific (Singapore), Asia Pacific (Sydney), Asia Pacific (Tokyo), Canada (Central), Europe (Frankfurt), Europe (Ireland), and Europe (Stockholm).

  • For the G.8X worker type, each worker maps to 8 DPU (32 vCPUs, 128 GB of memory) with 512GB disk, and provides 1 executor per worker. We recommend this worker type for jobs whose workloads contain your most demanding transforms, aggregations, joins, and queries. This worker type is available only for Glue version 3.0 or later Spark ETL jobs, in the same Amazon Web Services Regions as supported for the G.4X worker type.

  • For the Z.2X worker type, each worker maps to 2 M-DPU (8vCPUs, 64 GB of memory) with 128 GB disk, and provides up to 8 Ray workers based on the autoscaler.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with the session

GlueVersion.documentation: The Glue version determines the versions of Apache Spark and Python that Glue supports. The GlueVersion must be greater than 2.0.

Tags.documentation: The map of key value pairs (tags) belonging to the session.

Session.documentation: Returns the session object in the response.

CatalogId.documentation: The Catalog ID of the table.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database in the catalog in which the table resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table.

TableOptimizerConfiguration.documentation: A TableOptimizerConfiguration object representing the configuration of a table optimizer.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the Table. If none is supplied, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The catalog database in which to create the new table. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

Name.documentation: The unique identifier for the table within the specified database that will be created in the Glue Data Catalog.

TableInput.documentation: The TableInput object that defines the metadata table to create in the catalog.

PartitionIndexes.documentation: A list of partition indexes, PartitionIndex structures, to create in the table.

OpenTableFormatInput.documentation: Specifies an OpenTableFormatInput structure when creating an open format table.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.

WorkflowName.documentation: The name of the workflow associated with the trigger.

Schedule.documentation:
A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

This field is required when the trigger type is SCHEDULED.

Predicate.documentation:
A predicate to specify when the new trigger should fire.

This field is required when the trigger type is CONDITIONAL.

Actions.documentation: The actions initiated by this trigger when it fires.

StartOnCreation.documentation: Set to true to start SCHEDULED and CONDITIONAL triggers when created. True is not supported for ON_DEMAND triggers.

Tags.documentation: The tags to use with this trigger. You may use tags to limit access to the trigger. For more information about tags in Glue, see Amazon Web Services Tags in Glue in the developer guide.

EventBatchingCondition.documentation: Batch condition that must be met (specified number of events received or batch time window expired) before EventBridge event trigger fires.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.
The name of the usage profile.

Configuration.documentation: A ProfileConfiguration object specifying the job and session values for the profile.

Tags.documentation: A list of tags applied to the usage profile.

Name.documentation: The name of the usage profile that was created.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which to create the function. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which to create the function.

FunctionInput.documentation: A FunctionInput object that defines the function to create in the Data Catalog.

Name.documentation: The name to be assigned to the workflow. It should be unique within your account.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation:
A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow.

Run properties may be logged. Do not pass plaintext secrets as properties. Retrieve secrets from a Glue Connection, Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager or other secret management mechanism if you intend to use them within the workflow run.

Tags.documentation: The tags to be used with this workflow.

MaxConcurrentRuns.documentation: You can use this parameter to prevent unwanted multiple updates to data, to control costs, or in some cases, to prevent exceeding the maximum number of concurrent runs of any of the component jobs. If you leave this parameter blank, there is no limit to the number of concurrent workflow runs.

Name.documentation: The name of the workflow which was provided as part of the request.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This can't identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

CreateXMLClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies an XML classifier for CreateClassifier to create.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that this classifier was registered.

LastUpdated.documentation: The time that this classifier was last updated.

Delimiter.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what separates each column entry in the row.

QuoteSymbol.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what combines content into a single column value. It must be different from the column delimiter.

ContainsHeader.documentation: Indicates whether the CSV file contains a header.

Header.documentation: A list of strings representing column names.

DisableValueTrimming.documentation: Specifies not to trim values before identifying the type of column values. The default value is true.

AllowSingleColumn.documentation: Enables the processing of files that contain only one column.

CustomDatatypeConfigured.documentation: Enables the custom datatype to be configured.

Serde.documentation: Sets the SerDe for processing CSV in the classifier, which will be applied in the Data Catalog. Valid values are OpenCSVSerDe, LazySimpleSerDe, and None. You can specify the None value when you want the crawler to do the detection.

Name.documentation: The name of the transform node.

Inputs.documentation: The data inputs identified by their node names.

Code.documentation: The custom code that is used to perform the data transformation.

ClassName.documentation: The name defined for the custom code node class.

OutputSchemas.documentation: Specifies the data schema for the custom code transform.

CustomCode.documentation: Specifies a transform that uses custom code you provide to perform the data transformation. The output is a collection of DynamicFrames.

Name.documentation: A name for the custom pattern that allows it to be retrieved or deleted later. This name must be unique per Amazon Web Services account.

RegexString.documentation: A regular expression string that is used for detecting sensitive data in a custom pattern.

ContextWords.documentation:
A list of context words. If none of these context words are found within the vicinity of the regular expression the data will not be detected as sensitive data.

If no context words are passed only a regular expression is checked.

CustomEntityType.documentation: An object representing a custom pattern for detecting sensitive data across the columns and rows of your structured data.

DynamodbExport.documentation: Specifies the DynamoDB export configuration for the ELT operation.

DynamodbUnnestDDBJson.documentation: Specifies whether to unnest DynamoDB JSON format. When set to true, nested JSON structures in DynamoDB items are flattened.

DDBELTCatalogAdditionalOptions.documentation: Specifies additional options for DynamoDB ELT catalog operations.

DynamodbExport.documentation: Specifies the export type for DynamoDB data extraction. This parameter determines how data is exported from the DynamoDB table during the ELT process.

DynamodbUnnestDDBJson.documentation: A boolean value that specifies whether to unnest DynamoDB JSON format during data extraction. When set to true, the connector will flatten nested JSON structures from DynamoDB items. When set to false, the original DynamoDB JSON structure is preserved.

DynamodbTableArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the DynamoDB table to extract data from. This parameter specifies the source table for the ELT operation.

DynamodbS3Bucket.documentation: The name of the Amazon S3 bucket used for intermediate storage during the DynamoDB ELT process. This bucket is used to temporarily store exported DynamoDB data before it is processed by the ELT job.

DynamodbS3Prefix.documentation: The S3 object key prefix for files stored in the intermediate S3 bucket during the DynamoDB ELT process. This prefix helps organize and identify the temporary files created during data extraction.

DynamodbS3BucketOwner.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the owner of the S3 bucket specified in DynamodbS3Bucket. This parameter is required when the S3 bucket is owned by a different Amazon Web Services account than the one running the ELT job, enabling cross-account access to the intermediate storage bucket.

DynamodbStsRoleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services Security Token Service (STS) role to assume for accessing DynamoDB and S3 resources during the ELT operation. This role must have the necessary permissions to read from the DynamoDB table and write to the intermediate S3 bucket.

DDBELTConnectionOptions.documentation: Specifies connection options for DynamoDB ELT (Extract, Load, Transform) operations. This structure contains configuration parameters for connecting to and extracting data from DynamoDB tables using the ELT connector.

ResultsS3Prefix.documentation: The Amazon S3 prefix prepended to the results.

CloudWatchMetricsEnabled.documentation: Enable metrics for your data quality results.

ResultsPublishingEnabled.documentation: Enable publishing for your data quality results.

DQResultsPublishingOptions.documentation: Options to configure how your data quality evaluation results are published.

StopJobOnFailureTiming.documentation: When to stop job if your data quality evaluation fails. Options are Immediate or AfterDataLoad.

DQStopJobOnFailureOptions.documentation: Options to configure how your job will stop if your data quality evaluation fails.

EncryptionAtRest.documentation: Specifies the encryption-at-rest configuration for the Data Catalog.

ConnectionPasswordEncryption.documentation: When connection password protection is enabled, the Data Catalog uses a customer-provided key to encrypt the password as part of CreateConnection or UpdateConnection and store it in the ENCRYPTED_PASSWORD field in the connection properties. You can enable catalog encryption or only password encryption.

DataCatalogEncryptionSettings.documentation: Contains configuration information for maintaining Data Catalog security.

DataLakeAccess.documentation: Turns on or off data lake access for Apache Spark applications that access Amazon Redshift databases in the Data Catalog from any non-Redshift engine, such as Amazon Athena, Amazon EMR, or Glue ETL.

DataTransferRole.documentation: A role that will be assumed by Glue for transferring data into/out of the staging bucket during a query.

KmsKey.documentation: An encryption key that will be used for the staging bucket that will be created along with the catalog.

CatalogType.documentation: Specifies a federated catalog type for the native catalog resource. The currently supported type is aws:redshift.

DataLakeAccessProperties.documentation: Input properties to configure data lake access for your catalog resource in the Glue Data Catalog.

DataLakeAccess.documentation: Turns on or off data lake access for Apache Spark applications that access Amazon Redshift databases in the Data Catalog.

DataTransferRole.documentation: A role that will be assumed by Glue for transferring data into/out of the staging bucket during a query.

KmsKey.documentation: An encryption key that will be used for the staging bucket that will be created along with the catalog.

ManagedWorkgroupName.documentation: The managed Redshift Serverless compute name that is created for your catalog resource.

RedshiftDatabaseName.documentation: The default Redshift database resource name in the managed compute.

StatusMessage.documentation: A message that gives more detailed information about the managed workgroup status.

CatalogType.documentation: Specifies a federated catalog type for the native catalog resource. The currently supported type is aws:redshift.

DataLakeAccessPropertiesOutput.documentation: The output properties of the data lake access configuration for your catalog resource in the Glue Data Catalog.

DataLakePrincipalIdentifier.documentation: An identifier for the Lake Formation principal.

TotalRowsProcessed.documentation: The total number of rows that were processed during the data quality evaluation.

TotalRowsPassed.documentation: The total number of rows that passed all applicable data quality rules.

TotalRowsFailed.documentation: The total number of rows that failed one or more data quality rules.

TotalRulesProcessed.documentation: The total number of data quality rules that were evaluated.

TotalRulesPassed.documentation: The total number of data quality rules that passed their evaluation criteria.

TotalRulesFailed.documentation: The total number of data quality rules that failed their evaluation criteria.

DataQualityAggregatedMetrics.documentation: A summary of metrics showing the total counts of processed rows and rules, including their pass/fail statistics based on row-level results.

Name.documentation: The name of the data quality analyzer.

Description.documentation: A description of the data quality analyzer.

EvaluatedMetrics.documentation: A map of metrics associated with the evaluation of the analyzer.

DataQualityAnalyzerResult.documentation: Describes the result of the evaluation of a data quality analyzer.

DataQualityEncryptionMode.documentation:
The encryption mode to use for encrypting Data Quality assets. These assets include data quality rulesets, results, statistics, anomaly detection models and observations.

Valid values are SSEKMS for encryption using a customer-managed KMS key, or DISABLED.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key to be used to encrypt the data.

DataQualityEncryption.documentation: Specifies how Data Quality assets in your account should be encrypted.

CloudWatchMetricsEnabled.documentation: Whether or not to enable CloudWatch metrics.

ResultsS3Prefix.documentation: Prefix for Amazon S3 to store results.

CompositeRuleEvaluationMethod.documentation: Set the evaluation method for composite rules in the ruleset to ROW/COLUMN

DataQualityEvaluationRunAdditionalRunOpt.documentation: Additional run options you can specify for an evaluation run.

DatabaseName.documentation: A database name in the Glue Data Catalog.

TableName.documentation: A table name in the Glue Data Catalog.

CatalogId.documentation: A unique identifier for the Glue Data Catalog.

ConnectionName.documentation: The name of the connection to the Glue Data Catalog.

AdditionalOptions.documentation:
Additional options for the table. Currently there are two keys supported:

  • pushDownPredicate: to filter on partitions without having to list and read all the files in your dataset.

  • catalogPartitionPredicate: to use server-side partition pruning using partition indexes in the Glue Data Catalog.

PreProcessingQuery.documentation: SQL Query of SparkSQL format that can be used to pre-process the data for the table in Glue Data Catalog, before running the Data Quality Operation.

DataQualityGlueTable.documentation: The database and table in the Glue Data Catalog that is used for input or output data for Data Quality Operations.

ActualValue.documentation: The actual value of the data quality metric.

ExpectedValue.documentation: The expected value of the data quality metric according to the analysis of historical data.

LowerLimit.documentation: The lower limit of the data quality metric value according to the analysis of historical data.

UpperLimit.documentation: The upper limit of the data quality metric value according to the analysis of historical data.

DataQualityMetricValues.documentation: Describes the data quality metric value according to the analysis of historical data.

Description.documentation: A description of the data quality observation.

MetricBasedObservation.documentation: An object of type MetricBasedObservation representing the observation that is based on evaluated data quality metrics.

DataQualityObservation.documentation: Describes the observation generated after evaluating the rules and analyzers.

ResultId.documentation: A unique result ID for the data quality result.

ProfileId.documentation: The Profile ID for the data quality result.

Score.documentation: An aggregate data quality score. Represents the ratio of rules that passed to the total number of rules.

DataSource.documentation: The table associated with the data quality result, if any.

RulesetName.documentation: The name of the ruleset associated with the data quality result.

EvaluationContext.documentation: In the context of a job in Glue Studio, each node in the canvas is typically assigned some sort of name and data quality nodes will have names. In the case of multiple nodes, the evaluationContext can differentiate the nodes.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time when this data quality run started.

CompletedOn.documentation: The date and time when this data quality run completed.

JobName.documentation: The job name associated with the data quality result, if any.

JobRunId.documentation: The job run ID associated with the data quality result, if any.

RulesetEvaluationRunId.documentation: The unique run ID for the ruleset evaluation for this data quality result.

RuleResults.documentation: A list of DataQualityRuleResult objects representing the results for each rule.

AnalyzerResults.documentation: A list of DataQualityAnalyzerResult objects representing the results for each analyzer.

Observations.documentation: A list of DataQualityObservation objects representing the observations generated after evaluating the rules and analyzers.

AggregatedMetrics.documentation: A summary of DataQualityAggregatedMetrics objects showing the total counts of processed rows and rules, including their pass/fail statistics based on row-level results.

ResultId.documentation: The unique result ID for this data quality result.

DataSource.documentation: The table name associated with the data quality result.

JobName.documentation: The job name associated with the data quality result.

JobRunId.documentation: The job run ID associated with the data quality result.

StartedOn.documentation: The time that the run started for this data quality result.

DataSource.documentation: Filter results by the specified data source. For example, retrieving all results for an Glue table.

JobName.documentation: Filter results by the specified job name.

JobRunId.documentation: Filter results by the specified job run ID.

StartedAfter.documentation: Filter results by runs that started after this time.

StartedBefore.documentation: Filter results by runs that started before this time.

DataQualityResultFilterCriteria.documentation: Criteria used to return data quality results.

RunId.documentation: The unique run identifier associated with this run.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time when this run started.

DataSource.documentation: The data source (Glue table) associated with the recommendation run.

DataQualityRuleRecommendationRunDescript.documentation: Describes the result of a data quality rule recommendation run.

DataSource.documentation: Filter based on a specified data source (Glue table).

StartedBefore.documentation: Filter based on time for results started before provided time.

StartedAfter.documentation: Filter based on time for results started after provided time.

DataQualityRuleRecommendationRunFilter.documentation: A filter for listing data quality recommendation runs.

Name.documentation: The name of the data quality rule.

Description.documentation: A description of the data quality rule.

Result.documentation: A pass or fail status for the rule.

EvaluatedMetrics.documentation: A map of metrics associated with the evaluation of the rule.

RuleMetrics.documentation: A map containing metrics associated with the evaluation of the rule based on row-level results.

DataQualityRuleResult.documentation: Describes the result of the evaluation of a data quality rule.

RunId.documentation: The unique run identifier associated with this run.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time when the run started.

DataSource.documentation: The data source (an Glue table) associated with the run.

DataQualityRulesetEvaluationRunDescripti.documentation: Describes the result of a data quality ruleset evaluation run.

DataSource.documentation: Filter based on a data source (an Glue table) associated with the run.

StartedBefore.documentation: Filter results by runs that started before this time.

StartedAfter.documentation: Filter results by runs that started after this time.

Name.documentation: The name of the ruleset filter criteria.

Description.documentation: The description of the ruleset filter criteria.

CreatedBefore.documentation: Filter on rulesets created before this date.

CreatedAfter.documentation: Filter on rulesets created after this date.

LastModifiedBefore.documentation: Filter on rulesets last modified before this date.

LastModifiedAfter.documentation: Filter on rulesets last modified after this date.

TargetTable.documentation: The name and database name of the target table.

DataQualityRulesetFilterCriteria.documentation: The criteria used to filter data quality rulesets.

Name.documentation: The name of the data quality ruleset.

Description.documentation: A description of the data quality ruleset.

CreatedOn.documentation: The date and time the data quality ruleset was created.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The date and time the data quality ruleset was last modified.

RecommendationRunId.documentation: When a ruleset was created from a recommendation run, this run ID is generated to link the two together.

RuleCount.documentation: The number of rules in the ruleset.

DataQualityRulesetListDetails.documentation: Describes a data quality ruleset returned by GetDataQualityRuleset.

TableName.documentation: The name of the Glue table.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database where the Glue table exists.

CatalogId.documentation: The catalog id where the Glue table exists.

DataQualityGlueTable.documentation: An Glue table for Data Quality Operations.

DataSource.documentation: A data source (an Glue table) for which you want data quality results.

Name.documentation: The name of the database. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

LocationUri.documentation: The location of the database (for example, an HDFS path).

Parameters.documentation: These key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

CreateTime.documentation: The time at which the metadata database was created in the catalog.

CreateTableDefaultPermissions.documentation: Creates a set of default permissions on the table for principals. Used by Lake Formation. Not used in the normal course of Glue operations.

TargetDatabase.documentation: A DatabaseIdentifier structure that describes a target database for resource linking.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the database resides.

FederatedDatabase.documentation: A FederatedDatabase structure that references an entity outside the Glue Data Catalog.

Database.documentation: The Database object represents a logical grouping of tables that might reside in a Hive metastore or an RDBMS.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the database resides.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database.

DatabaseIdentifier.documentation: A structure that describes a target database for resource linking.

Name.documentation: The name of the database. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase when it is stored.

LocationUri.documentation: The location of the database (for example, an HDFS path).

Parameters.documentation:
These key-value pairs define parameters and properties of the database.

CreateTableDefaultPermissions.documentation: Creates a set of default permissions on the table for principals. Used by Lake Formation. Not used in the normal course of Glue operations.

TargetDatabase.documentation: A DatabaseIdentifier structure that describes a target database for resource linking.

FederatedDatabase.documentation: A FederatedDatabase structure that references an entity outside the Glue Data Catalog.

DatabaseInput.documentation: The structure used to create or update a database.

ProfileId.documentation: The ID of the data quality profile the statistic belongs to.

InclusionAnnotation.documentation: The inclusion annotation value to apply to the statistic.

Datatype.documentation: A structure representing the datatype of the value.

NumberOfNulls.documentation: The number of null values in the column.

NumberOfDistinctValues.documentation: The number of distinct values in a column.

DateColumnStatisticsData.documentation: Defines column statistics supported for timestamp data columns.

NumberOfNulls.documentation: The number of null values in the column.

NumberOfDistinctValues.documentation: The number of distinct values in a column.

DecimalColumnStatisticsData.documentation: Defines column statistics supported for fixed-point number data columns.

Scale.documentation: The scale that determines where the decimal point falls in the unscaled value.

DecimalNumber.documentation: Contains a numeric value in decimal format.

Returns the name of the blueprint that was deleted.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the catalog.

TableName.documentation: The name of the partitions' table.

PartitionValues.documentation: A list of partition values identifying the partition.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database where the table resides.

DeleteGlueIdentityCenterConfigurationReq.documentation: Request to delete the existing Glue Identity Center configuration.

DeleteGlueIdentityCenterConfigurationRes.documentation: Response from deleting the Glue Identity Center configuration.

IntegrationIdentifier.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the integration.

SourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the source for the integration.

TargetArn.documentation: The ARN of the target for the integration.

IntegrationName.documentation: A unique name for an integration in Glue.

IntegrationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the integration.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The ARN of a KMS key used for encrypting the channel.

AdditionalEncryptionContext.documentation: An optional set of non-secret keyvalue pairs that contains additional contextual information for encryption.

Tags.documentation: Metadata assigned to the resource consisting of a list of key-value pairs.

Status.documentation:
The status of the integration being deleted.

The possible statuses are:

  • CREATING: The integration is being created.

  • ACTIVE: The integration creation succeeds.

  • MODIFYING: The integration is being modified.

  • FAILED: The integration creation fails.

  • DELETING: The integration is deleted.

  • SYNCING: The integration is synchronizing.

  • NEEDS_ATTENTION: The integration needs attention, such as synchronization.

CreateTime.documentation: The time when the integration was created, in UTC.

Errors.documentation: A list of errors associated with the integration.

DataFilter.documentation: Selects source tables for the integration using Maxwell filter syntax.

ResourceArn.documentation: The connection ARN of the source, or the database ARN of the target.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table to be replicated.

JobName.documentation: The name of the job definition to delete.
The name of the job definition that was deleted.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier of the transform to delete.
The unique identifier of the transform that was deleted.

CatalogId.documentation: The catalog ID where the table resides.

TableName.documentation: Specifies the name of a table from which you want to delete a partition index.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table in question resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table that contains the partition to be deleted.

RegistryId.documentation: This is a wrapper structure that may contain the registry name and Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

RegistryName.documentation: The name of the registry being deleted.

RegistryArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the registry being deleted.

Status.documentation: The status of the registry. A successful operation will return the Deleting status.

PolicyHashCondition.documentation: The hash value returned when this policy was set.

ResourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the Glue resource for the resource policy to be deleted.

SchemaId.documentation: This is a wrapper structure that may contain the schema name and Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

SchemaArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema being deleted.

SchemaName.documentation: The name of the schema being deleted.

SchemaId.documentation: This is a wrapper structure that may contain the schema name and Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Versions.documentation:
A version range may be supplied which may be of the format:

  • a single version number, 5

  • a range, 5-8 : deletes versions 5, 6, 7, 8

SchemaVersionErrors.documentation: A list of SchemaVersionErrorItem objects, each containing an error and schema version.

Name.documentation: The name of the security configuration to delete.

Id.documentation: The ID of the session to be deleted.

RequestOrigin.documentation: The name of the origin of the delete session request.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

FunctionName.documentation: The name of the function definition to be deleted.
