Type.documentation: Specifies the parameter type in the config file of the dynamic transform.

ValidationRule.documentation: Specifies the validation rule in the config file of the dynamic transform.

ValidationMessage.documentation: Specifies the validation message in the config file of the dynamic transform.

Value.documentation: Specifies the value of the parameter in the config file of the dynamic transform.

ListType.documentation: Specifies the list type of the parameter in the config file of the dynamic transform.

IsOptional.documentation: Specifies whether the parameter is optional or not in the config file of the dynamic transform.

TransformConfigParameter.documentation: Specifies the parameters in the config file of the dynamic transform.

MlUserDataEncryption.documentation: An MLUserDataEncryption object containing the encryption mode and customer-provided KMS key ID.

TransformEncryption.documentation:
The encryption-at-rest settings of the transform that apply to accessing user data. Machine learning transforms can access user data encrypted in Amazon S3 using KMS.

Additionally, imported labels and trained transforms can now be encrypted using a customer provided KMS key.

Name.documentation: A unique transform name that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

TransformType.documentation: The type of machine learning transform that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

Status.documentation: Filters the list of machine learning transforms by the last known status of the transforms (to indicate whether a transform can be used or not). One of "NOT_READY", "READY", or "DELETING".

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

CreatedBefore.documentation: The time and date before which the transforms were created.

CreatedAfter.documentation: The time and date after which the transforms were created.

LastModifiedBefore.documentation: Filter on transforms last modified before this date.

LastModifiedAfter.documentation: Filter on transforms last modified after this date.

Schema.documentation: Filters on datasets with a specific schema. The Map<Column, Type> object is an array of key-value pairs representing the schema this transform accepts, where Column is the name of a column, and Type is the type of the data such as an integer or string. Has an upper bound of 100 columns.

TransformFilterCriteria.documentation: The criteria used to filter the machine learning transforms.

TransformType.documentation:
The type of machine learning transform.

For information about the types of machine learning transforms, see Creating Machine Learning Transforms.

FindMatchesParameters.documentation: The parameters for the find matches algorithm.

TransformParameters.documentation: The algorithm-specific parameters that are associated with the machine learning transform.

Column.documentation: The column to be used in the sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

SortDirection.documentation: The sort direction to be used in the sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

TransformSortCriteria.documentation: The sorting criteria that are associated with the machine learning transform.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger.

WorkflowName.documentation: The name of the workflow associated with the trigger.

Type.documentation: The type of trigger that this is.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

Predicate.documentation: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

EventBatchingCondition.documentation: Batch condition that must be met (specified number of events received or batch time window expired) before EventBridge event trigger fires.

Trigger.documentation: The information of the trigger represented by the trigger node.

TriggerNodeDetails.documentation: The details of a Trigger node present in the workflow.

Name.documentation: Reserved for future use.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

Predicate.documentation: The predicate of this trigger, which defines when it will fire.

EventBatchingCondition.documentation: Batch condition that must be met (specified number of events received or batch time window expired) before EventBridge event trigger fires.

TriggerUpdate.documentation: A structure used to provide information used to update a trigger. This object updates the previous trigger definition by overwriting it completely.

AuthorizedColumns.documentation: The list of columns the user has permissions to access.

IsRegisteredWithLakeFormation.documentation: A Boolean value indicating that the partition location is registered with Lake Formation.

Name.documentation: The name of the transform node.

Inputs.documentation: The node ID inputs to the transform.

UnionType.documentation:
Indicates the type of Union transform.

Specify ALL to join all rows from data sources to the resulting DynamicFrame. The resulting union does not remove duplicate rows.

Specify DISTINCT to remove duplicate rows in the resulting DynamicFrame.

Union.documentation: Specifies a transform that combines the rows from two or more datasets into a single result.

ResourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource from which to remove the tags.

Name.documentation: The name of the blueprint.

BlueprintLocation.documentation: Specifies a path in Amazon S3 where the blueprint is published.

Name.documentation: Returns the name of the blueprint that was updated.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the catalog.

CatalogInput.documentation: A CatalogInput object specifying the new properties of an existing catalog.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partitions in question reside. If none is supplied, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the partitions reside.

TableName.documentation: The name of the partitions' table.

PartitionValues.documentation: A list of partition values identifying the partition.

Errors.documentation: Error occurred during updating column statistics data.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partitions in question reside. If none is supplied, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the partitions reside.

TableName.documentation: The name of the partitions' table.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database where the table resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table for which to generate column statistics.

Role.documentation: The role used for running the column statistics.

Schedule.documentation: A schedule for running the column statistics, specified in CRON syntax.

ColumnNameList.documentation: A list of column names for which to run statistics.

CatalogID.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the database resides.

SecurityConfiguration.documentation: Name of the security configuration that is used to encrypt CloudWatch logs.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the connection resides. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

Name.documentation: The name of the connection definition to update.

ConnectionInput.documentation: A ConnectionInput object that redefines the connection in question.

Name.documentation: Name of the new crawler.

Role.documentation: The IAM role or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an IAM role that is used by the new crawler to access customer resources.

DatabaseName.documentation: The Glue database where results are stored, such as: arn:aws:daylight:us-east-1::database/sometable/*.

Schedule.documentation: A cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

Classifiers.documentation: A list of custom classifiers that the user has registered. By default, all built-in classifiers are included in a crawl, but these custom classifiers always override the default classifiers for a given classification.

TablePrefix.documentation: The table prefix used for catalog tables that are created.

SchemaChangePolicy.documentation: The policy for the crawler's update and deletion behavior.

RecrawlPolicy.documentation: A policy that specifies whether to crawl the entire dataset again, or to crawl only folders that were added since the last crawler run.

LineageConfiguration.documentation: Specifies data lineage configuration settings for the crawler.

LakeFormationConfiguration.documentation: Specifies Lake Formation configuration settings for the crawler.

Configuration.documentation: Crawler configuration information. This versioned JSON string allows users to specify aspects of a crawler's behavior. For more information, see Setting crawler configuration options.

CrawlerSecurityConfiguration.documentation: The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used by this crawler.

CrawlerName.documentation: The name of the crawler whose schedule to update.

Schedule.documentation: The updated cron expression used to specify the schedule (see Time-Based Schedules for Jobs and Crawlers. For example, to run something every day at 12:15 UTC, you would specify: cron(15 12 * * ? *).

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

Delimiter.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what separates each column entry in the row.

QuoteSymbol.documentation: A custom symbol to denote what combines content into a single column value. It must be different from the column delimiter.

ContainsHeader.documentation: Indicates whether the CSV file contains a header.

Header.documentation: A list of strings representing column names.

DisableValueTrimming.documentation: Specifies not to trim values before identifying the type of column values. The default value is true.

AllowSingleColumn.documentation: Enables the processing of files that contain only one column.

CustomDatatypes.documentation: Specifies a list of supported custom datatypes.

Serde.documentation: Sets the SerDe for processing CSV in the classifier, which will be applied in the Data Catalog. Valid values are OpenCSVSerDe, LazySimpleSerDe, and None. You can specify the None value when you want the crawler to do the detection.

UpdateCsvClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a custom CSV classifier to be updated.

Name.documentation: The name of the data quality ruleset.

Ruleset.documentation: A Data Quality Definition Language (DQDL) ruleset. For more information, see the Glue developer guide.

Name.documentation: The name of the data quality ruleset.

Ruleset.documentation: A Data Quality Definition Language (DQDL) ruleset. For more information, see the Glue developer guide.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the metadata database resides. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

Name.documentation: The name of the database to update in the catalog. For Hive compatibility, this is folded to lowercase.

DatabaseInput.documentation: A DatabaseInput object specifying the new definition of the metadata database in the catalog.

EndpointName.documentation: The name of the DevEndpoint to be updated.

PublicKey.documentation: The public key for the DevEndpoint to use.

AddPublicKeys.documentation: The list of public keys for the DevEndpoint to use.

DeletePublicKeys.documentation: The list of public keys to be deleted from the DevEndpoint.

CustomLibraries.documentation: Custom Python or Java libraries to be loaded in the DevEndpoint.

UpdateEtlLibraries.documentation: True if the list of custom libraries to be loaded in the development endpoint needs to be updated, or False if otherwise.

DeleteArguments.documentation: The list of argument keys to be deleted from the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

AddArguments.documentation:
The map of arguments to add the map of arguments used to configure the DevEndpoint.

Valid arguments are:

  • "--enable-glue-datacatalog": ""

You can specify a version of Python support for development endpoints by using the Arguments parameter in the CreateDevEndpoint or UpdateDevEndpoint APIs. If no arguments are provided, the version defaults to Python 2.

Scopes.documentation: A list of Identity Center scopes that define the updated permissions and access levels for the Glue configuration.

UpdateGlueIdentityCenterConfigurationReq.documentation: Request to update an existing Glue Identity Center configuration.

UpdateGlueIdentityCenterConfigurationRes.documentation: Response from updating an existing Glue Identity Center configuration.

Name.documentation: The name of the GrokClassifier.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches, such as Twitter, JSON, Omniture logs, Amazon CloudWatch Logs, and so on.

GrokPattern.documentation: The grok pattern used by this classifier.

CustomPatterns.documentation: Optional custom grok patterns used by this classifier.

UpdateGrokClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a grok classifier to update when passed to UpdateClassifier.

UpdateIcebergTableInput.documentation: The specific update operations to be applied to the Iceberg table, containing a list of updates that define the new state of the table including schema, partitions, and properties.

UpdateIcebergInput.documentation: Input parameters specific to updating Apache Iceberg tables in Glue Data Catalog, containing the update operations to be applied to an existing Iceberg table.

Updates.documentation: The list of table update operations that specify the changes to be made to the Iceberg table, including schema modifications, partition specifications, and table properties.

UpdateIcebergTableInput.documentation: Contains the update operations to be applied to an existing Iceberg table inGlue Data Catalog, defining the new state of the table metadata.

ResourceArn.documentation: The connection ARN of the source, or the database ARN of the target.

SourceProcessingProperties.documentation: The resource properties associated with the integration source.

TargetProcessingProperties.documentation: The resource properties associated with the integration target.

ResourceArn.documentation: The connection ARN of the source, or the database ARN of the target.

SourceProcessingProperties.documentation: The resource properties associated with the integration source.

TargetProcessingProperties.documentation: The resource properties associated with the integration target.

ResourceArn.documentation: The connection ARN of the source, or the database ARN of the target.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table to be replicated.

SourceTableConfig.documentation: A structure for the source table configuration.

TargetTableConfig.documentation: A structure for the target table configuration.

JobName.documentation: The name of the Glue job to be synchronized to or from the remote repository.

Provider.documentation: The provider for the remote repository. Possible values: GITHUB, AWS_CODE_COMMIT, GITLAB, BITBUCKET.

RepositoryName.documentation: The name of the remote repository that contains the job artifacts. For BitBucket providers, RepositoryName should include WorkspaceName. Use the format <WorkspaceName>/<RepositoryName>.

RepositoryOwner.documentation: The owner of the remote repository that contains the job artifacts.

BranchName.documentation: An optional branch in the remote repository.

Folder.documentation: An optional folder in the remote repository.

CommitId.documentation: A commit ID for a commit in the remote repository.

AuthStrategy.documentation: The type of authentication, which can be an authentication token stored in Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager, or a personal access token.

JobName.documentation: The name of the Glue job.
The name of the job definition to update.

JobUpdate.documentation: Specifies the values with which to update the job definition. Unspecified configuration is removed or reset to default values.

JobName.documentation: Returns the name of the updated job definition.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

JsonPath.documentation: A JsonPath string defining the JSON data for the classifier to classify. Glue supports a subset of JsonPath, as described in Writing JsonPath Custom Classifiers.

UpdateJsonClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies a JSON classifier to be updated.

TransformId.documentation: A unique identifier that was generated when the transform was created.

Name.documentation: The unique name that you gave the transform when you created it.

Description.documentation: A description of the transform. The default is an empty string.

Parameters.documentation: The configuration parameters that are specific to the transform type (algorithm) used. Conditionally dependent on the transform type.

Role.documentation: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions.

GlueVersion.documentation: This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

MaxCapacity.documentation:
The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.

When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

WorkerType.documentation:
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.

  • For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.

  • For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

  • For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

NumberOfWorkers.documentation: The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

Timeout.documentation: The timeout for a task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

MaxRetries.documentation: The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

TransformId.documentation: The unique identifier for the transform that was updated.

UpdateIcebergInput.documentation: Apache Iceberg-specific update parameters that define the table modifications to be applied, including schema changes, partition specifications, and table properties.

UpdateOpenTableFormatInput.documentation: Input parameters for updating open table format tables in GlueData Catalog, serving as a wrapper for format-specific update operations such as Apache Iceberg.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the partition to be updated resides. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table in question resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table in which the partition to be updated is located.

PartitionValueList.documentation: List of partition key values that define the partition to update.

PartitionInput.documentation:
The new partition object to update the partition to.

The Values property can't be changed. If you want to change the partition key values for a partition, delete and recreate the partition.

RegistryId.documentation: This is a wrapper structure that may contain the registry name and Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Description.documentation: A description of the registry. If description is not provided, this field will not be updated.

RegistryArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource name (ARN) of the updated registry.

SchemaId.documentation:
This is a wrapper structure to contain schema identity fields. The structure contains:

  • SchemaId$SchemaArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema. One of SchemaArn or SchemaName has to be provided.

  • SchemaId$SchemaName: The name of the schema. One of SchemaArn or SchemaName has to be provided.

SchemaVersionNumber.documentation: Version number required for check pointing. One of VersionNumber or Compatibility has to be provided.

Compatibility.documentation: The new compatibility setting for the schema.

SchemaArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema.

RegistryName.documentation: The name of the registry that contains the schema.

JobName.documentation: The name of the Glue job to be synchronized to or from the remote repository.

Provider.documentation: The provider for the remote repository. Possible values: GITHUB, AWS_CODE_COMMIT, GITLAB, BITBUCKET.

RepositoryName.documentation: The name of the remote repository that contains the job artifacts. For BitBucket providers, RepositoryName should include WorkspaceName. Use the format <WorkspaceName>/<RepositoryName>.

RepositoryOwner.documentation: The owner of the remote repository that contains the job artifacts.

BranchName.documentation: An optional branch in the remote repository.

Folder.documentation: An optional folder in the remote repository.

CommitId.documentation: A commit ID for a commit in the remote repository.

AuthStrategy.documentation: The type of authentication, which can be an authentication token stored in Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager, or a personal access token.

JobName.documentation: The name of the Glue job.

CatalogId.documentation: The Catalog ID of the table.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the database in the catalog in which the table resides.

TableName.documentation: The name of the table.

TableOptimizerConfiguration.documentation: A TableOptimizerConfiguration object representing the configuration of a table optimizer.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the table resides. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database in which the table resides. For Hive compatibility, this name is entirely lowercase.

Name.documentation: The unique identifier for the table within the specified database that will be created in the Glue Data Catalog.

TableInput.documentation: An updated TableInput object to define the metadata table in the catalog.

SkipArchive.documentation: By default, UpdateTable always creates an archived version of the table before updating it. However, if skipArchive is set to true, UpdateTable does not create the archived version.

TransactionId.documentation: The transaction ID at which to update the table contents.

VersionId.documentation: The version ID at which to update the table contents.

ViewUpdateAction.documentation: The operation to be performed when updating the view.

Force.documentation: A flag that can be set to true to ignore matching storage descriptor and subobject matching requirements.

Name.documentation: The name of the trigger to update.

TriggerUpdate.documentation: The new values with which to update the trigger.

Name.documentation: The name of the usage profile.

Configuration.documentation: A ProfileConfiguration object specifying the job and session values for the profile.

Name.documentation: The name of the usage profile that was updated.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog where the function to be updated is located. If none is provided, the Amazon Web Services account ID is used by default.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database where the function to be updated is located.

FunctionInput.documentation: A FunctionInput object that redefines the function in the Data Catalog.

Name.documentation: Name of the workflow to be updated.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation:
A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow.

Run properties may be logged. Do not pass plaintext secrets as properties. Retrieve secrets from a Glue Connection, Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager or other secret management mechanism if you intend to use them within the workflow run.

MaxConcurrentRuns.documentation: You can use this parameter to prevent unwanted multiple updates to data, to control costs, or in some cases, to prevent exceeding the maximum number of concurrent runs of any of the component jobs. If you leave this parameter blank, there is no limit to the number of concurrent workflow runs.

Name.documentation: The name of the workflow which was specified in input.
The name of the classifier.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This cannot identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

UpdateXMLClassifierRequest.documentation: Specifies an XML classifier to be updated.

TableLocation.documentation: The physical location of the Redshift table.

ConnectionName.documentation: The name of the connection to use to write to Redshift.

UpsertKeys.documentation: The keys used to determine whether to perform an update or insert.

UpsertRedshiftTargetOptions.documentation: The options to configure an upsert operation when writing to a Redshift target .

Name.documentation: The name of the usage profile.

CreatedOn.documentation: The date and time when the usage profile was created.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The date and time when the usage profile was last modified.

DatabaseName.documentation: The name of the catalog database that contains the function.

ClassName.documentation: The Java class that contains the function code.

CreateTime.documentation: The time at which the function was created.

CatalogId.documentation: The ID of the Data Catalog in which the function resides.

UserDefinedFunction.documentation: Represents the equivalent of a Hive user-defined function (UDF) definition.

ClassName.documentation: The Java class that contains the function code.

UserDefinedFunctionInput.documentation: A structure used to create or update a user-defined function.

IsProtected.documentation: You can set this flag as true to instruct the engine not to push user-provided operations into the logical plan of the view during query planning. However, setting this flag does not guarantee that the engine will comply. Refer to the engine's documentation to understand the guarantees provided, if any.

Definer.documentation: The definer of a view in SQL.

SubObjects.documentation: A list of table Amazon Resource Names (ARNs).

IsProtected.documentation: You can set this flag as true to instruct the engine not to push user-provided operations into the logical plan of the view during query planning. However, setting this flag does not guarantee that the engine will comply. Refer to the engine's documentation to understand the guarantees provided, if any.

Definer.documentation: The definer of a view in SQL.

Representations.documentation: A list of structures that contains the dialect of the view, and the query that defines the view.

SubObjects.documentation: A list of base table ARNs that make up the view.

ViewDefinitionInput.documentation: A structure containing details for creating or updating an Glue view.

DialectVersion.documentation: The version of the dialect of the query engine. For example, 3.0.0.

ViewOriginalText.documentation: The SELECT query provided by the customer during CREATE VIEW DDL. This SQL is not used during a query on a view (ViewExpandedText is used instead). ViewOriginalText is used for cases like SHOW CREATE VIEW where users want to see the original DDL command that created the view.

ViewExpandedText.documentation:
The expanded SQL for the view. This SQL is used by engines while processing a query on a view. Engines may perform operations during view creation to transform ViewOriginalText to ViewExpandedText. For example:

  • Fully qualified identifiers: SELECT * from table1 -> SELECT * from db1.table1

ValidationConnection.documentation: The name of the connection to be used to validate the specific representation of the view.

IsStale.documentation: Dialects marked as stale are no longer valid and must be updated before they can be queried in their respective query engines.

ViewRepresentation.documentation: A structure that contains the dialect of the view, and the query that defines the view.

Dialect.documentation: A parameter that specifies the engine type of a specific representation.

DialectVersion.documentation: A parameter that specifies the version of the engine of a specific representation.

ViewOriginalText.documentation: A string that represents the original SQL query that describes the view.

ValidationConnection.documentation: The name of the connection to be used to validate the specific representation of the view.

ViewExpandedText.documentation: A string that represents the SQL query that describes the view with expanded resource ARNs

ViewRepresentationInput.documentation: A structure containing details of a representation to update or create a Lake Formation view.

DialectVersion.documentation: The version of the dialect of the query engine. For example, 3.0.0.

ViewValidationText.documentation: The SELECT query that defines the view, as provided by the customer.

ViewValidation.documentation: A structure that contains information for an analytical engine to validate a view, prior to persisting the view metadata. Used in the case of direct UpdateTable or CreateTable API calls.

Name.documentation: The name of the workflow.

DefaultRunProperties.documentation: A collection of properties to be used as part of each execution of the workflow. The run properties are made available to each job in the workflow. A job can modify the properties for the next jobs in the flow.

CreatedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow was created.

LastModifiedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow was last modified.

LastRun.documentation: The information about the last execution of the workflow.

Graph.documentation: The graph representing all the Glue components that belong to the workflow as nodes and directed connections between them as edges.

MaxConcurrentRuns.documentation: You can use this parameter to prevent unwanted multiple updates to data, to control costs, or in some cases, to prevent exceeding the maximum number of concurrent runs of any of the component jobs. If you leave this parameter blank, there is no limit to the number of concurrent workflow runs.

BlueprintDetails.documentation: This structure indicates the details of the blueprint that this particular workflow is created from.

Workflow.documentation: A workflow is a collection of multiple dependent Glue jobs and crawlers that are run to complete a complex ETL task. A workflow manages the execution and monitoring of all its jobs and crawlers.

Nodes.documentation: A list of the the Glue components belong to the workflow represented as nodes.

Edges.documentation: A list of all the directed connections between the nodes belonging to the workflow.

WorkflowGraph.documentation: A workflow graph represents the complete workflow containing all the Glue components present in the workflow and all the directed connections between them.

Name.documentation: Name of the workflow that was run.

PreviousRunId.documentation: The ID of the previous workflow run.

WorkflowRunProperties.documentation: The workflow run properties which were set during the run.

StartedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow run was started.

CompletedOn.documentation: The date and time when the workflow run completed.

ErrorMessage.documentation: This error message describes any error that may have occurred in starting the workflow run. Currently the only error message is "Concurrent runs exceeded for workflow: foo."

Graph.documentation: The graph representing all the Glue components that belong to the workflow as nodes and directed connections between them as edges.

StartingEventBatchCondition.documentation: The batch condition that started the workflow run.

WorkflowRun.documentation: A workflow run is an execution of a workflow providing all the runtime information.

TotalActions.documentation: Total number of Actions in the workflow run.

TimeoutActions.documentation: Total number of Actions that timed out.

FailedActions.documentation: Total number of Actions that have failed.

StoppedActions.documentation: Total number of Actions that have stopped.

SucceededActions.documentation: Total number of Actions that have succeeded.

ErroredActions.documentation: Indicates the count of job runs in the ERROR state in the workflow run.

WaitingActions.documentation: Indicates the count of job runs in WAITING state in the workflow run.

WorkflowRunStatistics.documentation: Workflow run statistics provides statistics about the workflow run.

Name.documentation: The name of the classifier.

Classification.documentation: An identifier of the data format that the classifier matches.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that this classifier was registered.

LastUpdated.documentation: The time that this classifier was last updated.

RowTag.documentation: The XML tag designating the element that contains each record in an XML document being parsed. This can't identify a self-closing element (closed by />). An empty row element that contains only attributes can be parsed as long as it ends with a closing tag (for example, <row item_a="A" item_b="B"></row> is okay, but <row item_a="A" item_b="B" /> is not).

documentation:
Glue

Defines the public endpoint for the Glue service.
